name: Islamic Center of Southern California
mission: THE ISLAMIC CENTER OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA IS AN INDEPENDENT ORGANIZATION. ITS PURPOSE IS TO PRACTICE AND SHARE THE VALUES OF ISLAM IN THE UNITED STATES ...
zakatClaimEvidence: The Islamic Center of Southern California explicitly states on its 'Ways to Give' page: '3. Zakat & Sadaqah – Fulfill your religious obligations and assist those in need within our community.' Additionally, they have a dedicated 'Zakat Program' that provides 'essential financial aid to individuals and families in Los Angeles, CA, who are experiencing temporary hardships,' offering 'food coupons, rental assistance, and utility assistance.' Their donation page also lists 'Zakat al-Fitr' and 'Zakat al-Mal' as specific donation categories. (Source: https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQFKcKmEEW8c40BdPZLlY0lbDJId0hYcO16LPLWSHoBBYHYxxBRZevMnIoEYj1th4saRdqvhs8B1MyYciNM0vc_ZFGMQRzUTqggZbFATUSqAM3d319Kt76kkZlMj)

components.evidence: Accepts zakat (+2); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1); Asnaf: fi_sabilillah (+5)
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

alignment.rationale: Alignment 29/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, religious cultural cause area

components.improvement_suggestion: Track and report beneficiary counts to enable cost analysis
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: Build working capital reserves to 1-3 months of operating expenses
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes for 3+ years
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with causal pathway
components.name: Theory of Change

judge_issues.message: The impact rationale mentions the program expense ratio but doesn't explicitly address the missing data for cost per beneficiary, the absent theory of change, and the minimal board governance, all of which significantly contributed to the low impact score.
The amal_score rationale mentions the balance between community presence and financial metrics but doesn't explicitly highlight the significant risk deductions due to the low program expense ratio.
BBB name 'Southern Poverty Law Center' may not match 'Islamic Center of Southern California' (similarity: 50%)

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Program expense ratio critically low: 50%

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Islamic Center of Southern California earns 29/100 due to good alignment and limited impact, with zakat compliance (significant risk deductions applied).

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 29/50, the organization shows a medium fit for Muslim donors, particularly as it is zakat-eligible [4]. It addresses urgent religious and cultural needs through its mission to share Islamic values in the United States [3].
dimension_explanations.impact: The center's impact score of 7/50 reflects its focus on capacity building through religious education and social services [3]. While it maintains a strong working capital of 17.2 months, the program expense ratio of 49.6% indicates that less than half of its $2,134,893 total revenue is spent directly on program activities [1][2].

strengths: Maintains a robust liquidity position with 17.2 months of working capital [1]

baseline_narrative.summary: The Islamic Center of Southern California is an independent organization dedicated to practicing and sharing Islamic values through diverse community programs [3]. During the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported a total revenue of $2,134,893 to support its religious and social missions [2].

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize local Islamic institutional stability and community services in Southern California over high programmatic efficiency.
donor_motivations: Want to support one of the oldest Islamic institutions in Southern California
Value a wide range of local services from food pantries to youth groups
Prefer organizations with high financial reserves and zero fundraising costs
giving_considerations: A significant portion of donations goes toward administrative and facility costs
Recent revenue trends show a decline in overall funding
Limited data is available regarding the specific number of people served
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-efficiency direct aid or those who require rigorous third-party impact data.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects basic financial reporting via Form 990 without external impact evaluations or verified outcome metrics.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The center creates impact by providing a physical and spiritual space for the Muslim community, though the causal pathway is not formally documented.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that community programs are effectively meeting the needs of the local population.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a <cite id="2">declining revenue trend of -9.1%</cite>, the organization has significant capacity to absorb new funding to restore program levels.

peer_comparison.differentiator: The center has <cite id="1">higher working capital (17.2 months)</cite> than many peers but a <cite id="1">lower program ratio (49.6%)</cite> than the 81.7% median.

strengths.detail: The organization maintains <cite id="1">17.2 months of working capital</cite>, providing a significant buffer for long-term operational stability.
The center spends <cite id="1">$0.00 to raise every $1</cite> in contributions, ensuring that no donor funds are diverted to third-party solicitors.
Beyond religious services, the center provides <cite id="3">food pantry support, youth groups, and marriage services</cite> to the Southern California community.

strengths_deep_dive: The Islamic Center of Southern California demonstrates strong internal governance through its <cite id="1">100% independent board members</cite>, ensuring objective oversight of its $2.1 million operations. Its financial model is highly sustainable from a liquidity standpoint, as evidenced by its <cite id="2">$3,369,879 in total assets</cite> compared to only <cite id="2">$594,210 in total liabilities</cite>. This fiscal conservatism allows the center to maintain essential services like its <cite id="3">Sunday School and Muslim Youth Group (MYG)</cite> even during periods of fluctuating revenue.
rich_narrative.summary: The Islamic Center of Southern California (ICSC) operates as an independent religious and cultural hub, dedicated to practicing and sharing Islamic values within the United States. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported <cite id="2">total revenue of $2,134,893</cite>, primarily driven by <cite id="2">$2,111,995 in public contributions</cite>. The center serves as a multi-functional institution, offering a wide array of community services including <cite id="3">a food pantry, Sunday school, and funeral services</cite>. Despite its long-standing presence in the region, the organization maintains a <cite id="2">program expense ratio of 49.6%</cite>, which is notably lower than the <cite id="1">peer program ratio median of 81.7%</cite> for similar religious and cultural organizations. Financially, the center is characterized by significant liquidity, holding <cite id="1">17.2 months of working capital</cite> in working capital. While the center successfully manages <cite id="1">highly efficient fundraising operations</cite> with a cost of $0.00 per $1 raised, its overall impact score is constrained by limited public data regarding specific beneficiary outcomes and a <cite id="2">3-year revenue CAGR of -9.1%</cite>, indicating a recent contraction in funding levels.
